==Chinese==
{{zh-forms|s=橄榄}}
{{wikipedia|lang=zh}}

===Etymology===
Borrowed from a Tai-Kadai language in ancient times. Compare {{cog|za|gyamj||olive}}, {{cog|lo|ເຫລືອມ||{{taxlink|Canarium kerrii|species|noshow=1}} Craib}}, {{m|lo|ເກິມ||{{taxlink|Canarium venosum|species|noshow=1}} Craib}}, as well as {{cog|mkh-mvi|tlám||olive}} (from earlier < ''*klam''; Modern {{m|vi|trám}}).

===Noun===
{{zh-noun}}

# [[Chinese olive]] ({{taxlink|Canarium album|species|noshow=1}})
# European [[olive]] ({{taxlink|Olea europaea|species|noshow=1}})

====Usage notes====
It's easy to confuse the European and Chinese olives, because they're often referred to by the same name. Fortunately, there's little overlap in use: the European olive is packaged for food in brine (it's inedible fresh), or as oil pressed from the fruit. The Chinese olive is dried or candied, or the nuts are eaten. The European olive is foreign and mentioned in the [[Bible]], as well as in the context of the [[Middle East]] and [[Europe]], while the Chinese olive is native and [[East Asia]]n.
